EZ Water Overview

Exclusion Zone Research — The Fourth Phase of Water

EZ water (Exclusion Zone water) is a concept from the research of Dr. Gerald Pollack at the University of Washington.

Key claim: Water near hydrophilic surfaces forms an ordered layer that excludes particles and has different properties than bulk water.

The Research → Structured Water Basics →

The Research

Dr. Pollack's lab has documented:

  • Exclusion zones — regions near surfaces that exclude microspheres
  • Charge separation — negative charge in EZ, positive in bulk
  • Light responsiveness — EZ grows with infrared light exposure
  • Gel-like properties — different viscosity and density than bulk

Published in "The Fourth Phase of Water" (2013) and peer-reviewed journals.

Evidence Levels

Well-Documented

  • Exclusion zone formation near hydrophilic surfaces
  • Charge separation phenomenon
  • Light-induced growth of EZ layer

Still Debated

  • Exact molecular structure of EZ water
  • Health implications of EZ water
  • How long EZ properties persist

Practical Implications

For your water exploration:

  • Surfaces matter — container material may influence water behavior
  • Light matters — IR exposure may affect interface layers
  • Time matters — water near surfaces stabilizes differently
  • Measure over time — track ORP/pH changes at intervals

items.question: Is EZ water the same as structured water?
items.answer: EZ water is a specific type of structured/interfacial water documented in research. 'Structured water' is a broader term.

items.question: Can I make EZ water at home?
items.answer: You can create conditions that favor EZ formation (hydrophilic surfaces, light exposure) but measuring it requires specialized equipment.

items.question: Is Dr. Pollack's research accepted?
items.answer: His observations are reproducible; interpretation and implications are still debated in mainstream science.
